title: 114_hr470
content: The "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015" allows for the disposal of isolated National Forest System land in Georgia to be used for more efficient purposes. Proceeds from the land sales will be used by the Forest Service to acquire land for National Forest purposes in the state. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange National Forest System land in Georgia totaling 3,841 acres. Maps of the land are available for public inspection. The boundaries may be modified based on land management considerations. The Forest Supervisor of Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest can modify boundaries of land to be sold or exchanged based on land management considerations. Land sold under this Act will be conveyed by quitclaim deed with the Secretary reserving any necessary rights. The land cannot be sold for less than market value as determined by appraisal. Appraisals must adhere to specific standards. The Secretary can sell land under the Act at market value determined by appraisal or competitive bid. Appraisals must meet specific standards and be approved by the Secretary. Consideration for sales or exchanges must be paid in cash. The Secretary has the option to sell land publicly or privately, including through competitive sale methods. The Secretary has the authority to sell land at public or private sale, including competitive auction. They can also solicit offers and use brokers to facilitate the sale, paying commissions from the proceeds. The Secretary shall deposit sale proceeds in the fund established under the Sisk Act for land acquisition in Georgia. Funds can be used without further appropriation, but only with the landowner's written consent.
